Processing forecasts#

Submodules#

ensemble learning#

Ensemble learning methods can be used for improoving forecasting models

class processing_forecasts.ensemble_learning.ensemble_learning(forecasts, validation_data)[source]#

Bases: object

This class embeds the ensemble learning methods:

Methods:

  • Bagging: multiple independent models are trained on different subsets of the training data, and their predictions are combined through averaging, voting or weighted averaging (Random Forest).

  • Boosting: multiple models are trained sequentially, with each new model attempting to correct the errors made by the previous models (Gradient Boosting algorithm).

  • Stacking: multiple models with different characteristics are trained and their predictions are combined using a meta-model(Decision Tree Regressor).

Attributes:

  • forecasts (list) : list of the forecasts to use

  • validation_data (numpy array) : numpy array of the validation data

Import and use:

from src.processing_forecasts.ensemble_learning import ensemble_learning

ensemble_learning = ensemble_learning(forecasts, validation_data)

bagged_forecast = ensemble_learning.bagging()

boosted_forecast = ensemble_learning.boosting()

stacked_forecast = ensemble_learning.stacking()

bagging()[source]#

This method implements the bagging ensemble method.

boosting()[source]#

This method implements the boosting ensemble method.

stacking()[source]#

This method implements the stacking ensemble method.

computes the overlay_dx metric

Import and usage:

from src.processing_forecasts.metrics import Evaluate

metrics = Evaluate(target_values = df[“target_values”], prediction = df[“prediction”])

metrics.evaluate()

metrics.spikes_covering()

results, aeras = metrics.overlay_dx_visualisation_df(df,100,0.1,0.1)

calculate_overlay_percentages_multi(forecasts, max_percentage, min_percentage, step)[source]#

calculate_overlay_percentages_multi: calculate the overlay percentages for multiple forecasts

Parameters:

  • forecasts (dict) – dictionary of forecasts, keys are the names of the forecasts (str), values are the forecasts (np.array)

  • max_percentage (int) – maximum percentage of the range to calculate

  • min_percentage (int) – minimum percentage of the range to calculate

  • step (int) – step size for the percentages

overlay_dx(x, y=None)[source]#

overlay_dx computes the percentage of values where the absolute difference between the forecast and actual values is less than or equal to x

overlay_dx_moo(forecasts_df, max_percentage, min_percentage, step)[source]#

overlay method for the multi objective approach

overlay_dx_visualisation_df(forecasts_df, max_percentage, min_percentage, step)[source]#

calculate_overlay_percentages_multi: calculate the overlay percentages for multiple forecasts

Parameters:

  • forecasts_df (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame of forecasts, where columns are the names of the forecasts and rows are the forecast values

  • max_percentage (int) – maximum percentage of the range to calculate

  • min_percentage (int) – minimum percentage of the range to calculate

  • step (int) – step size for the percentages

Description:

Overlay_dx is a score associated with a visualisation that provides a better understanding of the performance of our forecasts. Overlay_dx consists of several measures of the overlay metric, which draws an interval around the target values and returns the percentage of forecast values that fall within this interval. Overlay_dx calculates different measures of the overlay metric by reducing the size of its interval.

A score of 77% represents how well the forecasted values align with the actual values at different thresholds. It indicates that the achieved score is 77% of the maximum possible score, where perfect alignment would occur at all thresholds.

The score reflects the overall accuracy relative to the ideal scenario. The higher the score, the better the alignment between forecasted and actual values, while a lower score suggests larger deviations.

The overlay curve visualization is the key advantage of this metric. It allows for a quick assessment of model performance. By observing the curve, you can easily identify where significant deviations from the ideal scenario occur, helping to point areas for improvement.

Unlike other metrics, such as Mean Absolute Error, the overlay curve is less impacted by outliers, providing a more comprehensive view of accuracy. In summary, the overlay curve offers an intuitive and concise way to evaluate model performance, providing insights into accuracy across different thresholds and highlighting areas for optimization.

rmse: root mean squared error

multi objective optimization#

Multi objective Optimization can find the best weighted average in regard of multiple metrics to minimize and scores to maximize.

class processing_forecasts.multi_objective_optimization.MyProblem(df, forecasts_cols, target_col, max_evaluations)[source]#

Bases: Problem

MyProblem: class to define the multi-objective optimization problem

Three objectives:

  1. Minimize the MAE

  2. Minimize the RMSE

  3. Maximize the overlay_dx_score

Find the best weights for the weighted average forecast according to the three objectives.

how it works: https://platypus.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting-started.html#defining-a-problem

df#

pandas dataframe with the forecasts and the target values

Type:

pd.DataFrame

target_values#

target values

Type:

np.array

forecasts#

dictionary of forecasts, keys are the approach names of the forecasts (str), values are the forecasts (np.array)

Type:

dict

Import and usage:

from src.processing_forecasts.multi_objective_optimization import find_best_weights

best_weights , best_result = find_best_weights(df, forecasts_cols, target_col, max_evaluations)

evaluate(solution)[source]#

Evaluate the solution

mae_loss_function(weights)[source]#

Compute the MAE between the actual data and the weighted average forecast

overlay_dx_gain_function(weights)[source]#

Compute the overlay_dx_score between the actual data and the weighted average forecast

rmse_loss_function(weights)[source]#

Compute the RMSE between the actual data and the weighted average forecast

processing_forecasts.multi_objective_optimization.find_best_weights(df, forecasts_cols, target_col, max_evaluations)[source]#
find_best_weights: find the best weights for the weighted average of forecasts according to the three objectives.
Three objectives:

  1. Minimize the MAE

  2. Minimize the RMSE

  3. Maximize the overlay_dx_score

Find the best weights for the weighted average forecast according to the three objectives.

how it works: https://platypus.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting-started.html#defining-a-problem

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – pandas dataframe with the forecasts and the target values

  • num_variables (int) – number of variables

  • target_values (np.array) – target values

  • forecasts (dict) – dictionary of forecasts, keys are the approach names of the forecasts (str), values are the forecasts (np.array)

Import: from src.processing_forecasts.multi_objective_optimization import find_best_weights
